metadata.title: Supplemental Information Structural Determination of the Broadly Reactive Anti-IGHV1-69 Anti-idiotypic Antibody G6 and Its Idiotope

body_text.text: The set of G6-derived IGHV1-69 phagemid-Abs was analyzed for IGHD diversity and frequency and compared with a set of scFv IGHV1-69 Abs obtained from sequencing the DNA phagemid-Ab library using PacBio NGS approach. B) A random set of IGHV1-69 hv1263 allelebased Abs (n = 75) derived from the PacBio Ab dataset was examined for the occurrence of CDR-H2 F54, which appears in 8 Abs (pink highlights). The VH segments of IGHV1-69 F-allele germline based Abs that were isolated from the G6 panning assays, Related to Figure 7 . The tables show VH amino acid sequences of IGHV1-69 Fallele germline based phagemid-Abs that were eluted from the G6 panning assays. At the top of alignments are the reference IGHV1-69 V-segments and below are the VH sequences ordered with the highest to the lowest similarity to the group's reference V-segment gene. Dots represent identical amino acids to the reference V-segment. Ab-clones with the blue dot-marking share identical VHs, but different VLs. Ab-clones with red dot-marking share identical VH and identical or highly similar VLs (for some of the Ab VLs sequence information is incomplete). 4  5 101  102  103  104  105  106  107  108  109  110  111  112  113  114  115  116  117  118  119  120  121  122  123  124  125  126  127  128  129  130  131  132  133  134  135  136  137  138  139  140  141  142 A selection of phagemid-Ab clones from the G6 panning assay were purified by PEG-precipitation and were analyzed for binding activities against G6 and hG6.3 using MSD ELISA assay. AUC values were calculated from four used dilution points (1e10, 1e11, 1e12 and 1e13 phagemid-Ab particles/ml) and key immunogenetic parameters are given for each Ab. The HV1-69-sBnAb D80 was used as a positive control, while the HV1-69-sBnAb F10 was used as a negative control. Three non-IGHV1-69 Abs were also included, which were all defined by AUC values similar to the negative control, and in red are the IGHV1-69 phagemid-Abs that were defined by low AUC signal that was outside the mean standard deviation range that was calculated for the 19 tested IGHV1-69 phagemid-Abs. (B) The VH amino acid sequences of the IGHV1-69 phagemid-Ab clones. The core of the binding idiotope on D80, which comprises of CDR-H2 residues M53 to N58 (green), bound to hG6.3 (blue) in the crystal structure. (B) The same CDR-H2 core binding idiotope displayed in surface representation where the hG6.3 surface residues are colored blue to red for increasing contribution to intermolecular van der Waals contacts, and the hydrogen bonds are depicted with black dashed lines. The CDR-H2 residues G55 and T56 intimately interact with hG6.3, and larger side chains are not likely to be accommodated at these positions due to clashes with the surrounding hG6.3 residues, G55 with Y97H and T56 with N32L.

BIBREF1.title: Dynamics of preferential substrate recognition in HIV-1 protease: redefining the substrate envelope

BIBREF2.title: Mechanism of substrate recognition by drug-resistant human immunodeficiency virus type 1 protease variants revealed by a novel structural intermediate

FIGREF0.text: The pocket in the binding site of hG6.3, Related to Figure 3 (A) The pocket within the binding site of hG6.3 that remains upon binding D80 is shown in orange with hG6.3 shown in purple and D80 shown in light green. (B) The residues that line the pocket in hG6.3 are shown in purple and the pocket is shown in orange. Crystal structures of the HV1-69-sBnAb D80 that bears the hG6.3 idiotope alone and in complex with hG6.3, Related to Figures 3, 4 and 5. (A) Overview of the crystal structure of the D80 Fab fragment bound to the hG6.3 Fab fragment. (B) The binding angle between the two Fab fragments is 149 degrees. The elbow angles in the hG6.3 and D80 structures are 172 and 173 degrees, respectively. (C) Overview of the crystal structure of the unbound D80 Fab fragment. One molecule from the asymmetric unit is shown. The elbow angle is 174 and 176 degrees in each molecule of the asymmetric unit. (D)

QVQLVQSGAEVKKPGSSVKVSCTSS---EVTFSSFAISWVRQAPGQGLEWLGGISPMFGTPNYAQKFQGRVTITADQSTRTAYMDLRSLRSEDTAVYYCARSPSYICSGGTCVF-----Binding of IGHV1-69 germline based Abs to hG6.3 based on the D80-hG6.3 complex crystal structure, Related to Figures 2 and 7. Two IGHV1-69 germline-based Abs comprised of non-mutated V-segments, 3B4 and 1-69/B3, were modeled as bound to hG6.3 (purple) using their unbound structures and the D80-hG6.3 crystal structure. The overview of the modeled structures for (A) 3B4 Fab variable domain (pink) and (B) 1-69/B3 Fab (orange) bound to hG6.3 (purple). Close-up views of the interface and heavy chain CDRs in the modeled bound structures of (C) 3B4 (pink) and (D) 1-69/B3 (orange), superimposed with CDR-H2 of D80 (green) in the crystal structure bound to hG6.3 (purple surface). The critical H54 F and H58 N side chains are displayed as sticks. The hG6.3 core binding idiotope, Related to Figure 3. (A)

TABREF0.text: Crystallographic Statistics for the Structures of D80, Related to Figure 3. Statistics for crystallographic data collection and structure determination for D80 Fab fragment bound to hG6.3 Fab, and the unbound D80 Fab fragment. The values in parentheses are for the highest-resolution shell.

TABREF2.text: The distance difference plot of the heavy chain alpha carbons of the D80 fragment, comparing the bound and unbound structures of D80. This method reduces bias that can be introduced by comparing structures using a structural alignment. The warm (red-yellow) and cool (blue-cyan) colored regions of the plot highlight decreasing and increasing internal distances, respectively, between bound and unbound structures of D80, where white indicates no or minimal change. (E) A structural alignment of the bound (dark green) and unbound (light green) VH domain of D80. (F) The average distance difference value for each residue was mapped onto the unbound structure of D80 and colored on a rainbow scale, where the residues displaying the greatest overall differences in magnitude are indicated in red, and dark blue indicates no or minimal change.

back_matter.text: Glycerol stock of two of the phagemid libraries that constitutes the Mehta I/II 27-billion-member phage display library were grown to logarithmic phase and then the DNA was extracted using standard DNA extraction approaches. Both libraries were digested with NcoI and NotI which yielded the whole VH+VL sequence. A 1:1 mixture of the digested material was sent to the University of Maryland, Baltimore, Institute for Genome Sciences for sequencing using the PacBio's CCS approach. Postsequencing, the data were quality controlled by using a script that maintained sequences defined by minimum quality score of 20 in at least 97% of the sequence bases and by using the Geneious software Version 7.1.
back_matter.section: Supplementary experimental and computational methods section PacBio analysis of the phagemid-Ab library

back_matter.text: Molecular graphics images and elbow angles were calculated using PyMOL (Schrodinger, 2010) . The mutagenesis tool in PyMOL was used to model the F54L mutation. Distance difference and van der Waals calculations were performed using in-house scripts, as described previously (Ozen et al., 2011; Prabu-Jeyabalan et al., 2006) . Distance difference calculations were used to eliminate superposition bias when comparing bound and unbound structures by comparing the internal distances between residue pairs (alpha carbon atoms) within the two structures (Prabu-Jeyabalan et al., 2006) . Pocket volume analysis was performed using the POVME pocket volume analysis tool (Durrant et al., 2014) . Hydrogen bonds were detected using the PyMOL polar contacts tool, where h_bond_cutoff_center was set to 3.6 Å and h_bond_cutoff_edge was set to 3.2 Å (Schrodinger, 2010) . Pi-stacking interactions or pi-atom interactions were detected in Maestro and defined using the default values as follows: A face-to-face pi stacking interaction is defined as an angle between ring planes of less than 30 degrees and a distance between ring centroids of less than 4.4 Å. An edge-to-face pi stacking interaction is defined as an angle between ring planes that is between 60 and 120 degrees, and a distance between ring centroids that is less than 5.5 Å (Schrodinger, 2015) . A pi-atom interaction is defined as a distance between an atom and a ring centroid of less than 6.6 Å, and the angle between the ring plane and the line between the cation center and the ring centroid does not deviate from the perpendicular by more than 30 degrees.

Selected phagemid-Ab clones from the G6 column assay were analyzed for binding to G6 and hG6.3 by using the MSD technology platform. 384-well high bind plates were coated overnight at 4°C with 6.25 ng of G6 or hG6.3. The plates were blocked with 2% BSA/PBS and diluted phagemid-Abs in 2% milk/PBST were added to the plates for 1 hour at 37°C. After washing of the plates, sulfo-taggedanti-M13 was added for 1-hour incubation at 37°C. Finally, plates were washed and read buffer was added.
back_matter.section: Binding assays of phagemid-Ab clones to G6 and hG6.3

back_matter.text: The IGHV1-69 Abs 1-69/B3 and 3B4 VH and VL genes were synthesized based on the sequences reported within their PDB files 5I18 and 5C2B, respectively. The genes were cloned into pFarber phagemid vector, which express the Abs as scFv, and binding of 1-69/B3 and 3B4 as phagemid-Abs to G6.3 and hG6.3 was analyzed by performing a standard ELISA assay using MSD technology platform similar as described above. The unbound crystal structures of 1-69/B3 and 3B4 were aligned onto the D80 in the cocrystal structure solved here of D80 bound to hG6.3. The structural alignment was done in PyMOL using the CDR-H2 loops of the two Abs, followed by standard energy minimization of the whole complex using Protein Prep Wizard (Schrodinger Software Suite) .
back_matter.section: Synthesizing IGHV1-69 Abs 1-69/B3 and 3B4, testing their binding activities to G6 and hG6.3, and modeling the bound structures
